Quick Facts

EXIT   X

MONITORING AND REPORTING OBLIGATIONS

Page

Table of Contents

 

A threshold transaction involves transferring $10,000 or more using physical currency (such as a country's notes and coins) or e- currency (internet-based currency backed by precious metal or bullion).

 

Your organisation must report to AUSTRAC if it provides a designated service involving a threshold transaction. A threshold transaction report (TTR) must be made within 10 business days after the transaction occurs.  

 

What a TTR contains

 

Click on the terms for more details

•         the individual customer's full name

•         date of birth

•         business name

•         full address

•         phone number

•         ABN

•         the organisation's name

•         description of its business structure

•         full address for the main place of business

•         ABN or CAN

•         phone number

•         details of the person conducting the threshold transaction

 

Failure to report suspicious transactions in time or at all can attract fines up to:

 

•         $18 million for companies

•         $3.6 million for individuals

TTRs are not required for:

 

•         designated services provided via a reporting entity's permanent establishment in a foreign country

•         Australian financial services licence holders who arrange for a person to receive a designated service
